results.title: Problem of conservation: Our natural resources
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Provides a broad overview of developing crises in world natural resources. Establishes man’s reliance upon and misuse of such resources and describes current conservation efforts. Produced in collaboration with Allan A. Sollers, author of “Ours is our Earth.”
results.description:

results.title: Soil
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Shows what soil is and how it is formed - then illustrates the damaging effects of water and wind erosion. Another damaging depletion is the loss of nutrients in the soil. Illustrates with on the spot examples of how the U.S. conservation service in 1969 combated these projects that range from contour ploughing to land use planning.

results.title: Water
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems of conservation”
Shows innovative ways to increase water supplies - percolation ponds, desalination of salt water, artificial weather control. Indicates that pollution control is equally important in conserving and purifying present water supplies.
Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.description:

results.title: Forest and range
results.creator_credit: John Walker and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Environment in crisis: problems of conservation”.
Presents “multiple use programmes” in which American forests are used for produce in addition to recreation. This program juxtaposes the need for food, lumber and recreation against the desire to retain undeveloped areas.
results.description:

results.title: Maintaining good working conditions
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Mode-Art Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
Presents several cases where an improvement in working conditions resulted in increased production. The importance of the part which must be played by supervisors in maintaining good working conditions is stressed.

results.title: Maintaining quality standards
results.creator_credit: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Mode-Art Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
Various scenes emphasise the nature of quality standards. The role of the supervisor in maintaining quality as well as quantity is made clear by incidents involving poor instruction, carelessness, and lack of pride in good workmanship.
results.creator_credit_for_label: F.E. Brooker, United States. Office of Education and Mode-Art Pictures

results.title: Introducing the new worker to his job
results.creator_credit: United States. Office of Education and Caraval Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in Supervision”.
A new worker is being started in his job; his induction is done poorly, and the worker shows considerable dissatisfaction with his treatment. A demonstration of how a worker should be introduced to his new job is then given.

results.title: Using visual aids in training
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Office of Education. Division of Visual Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Problems in supervision”
An instructor, teaching his class the use of the micrometer, follows a carefully planned procedure involving the use of an instructional sound film, a film strip, and a study guide.
